text: If not for this slight alcoholic astringency on a few sips that didnt sit well with the overall tartness of this beer, it would be a 5 for me. Granted Im probably a bit more liberal with my 5s than most, but all Im saying is that this is a really good beer.
Bottle at Volo. A crystal clear gold with a tart coriander and mellow lemon aroma. Light bodied and semi-sweet. The flavor is wheat, tart, lemon, coriander and mild spices. Good. 3.6-7

pours hazy/cloudy bright yellow with a small white head, reviving and leaving a delicate lacing. crispy pils, lean fruitiness - apples, white grapes and peaches; very herbal and spicy - coriander and other plants/herbs, low-fi bretts, soft winey notes, light acidity - nicely lactic, soft barreling notes - never tannic, pepper, sulfur traces. lively carbonation, light body - slightly watery, gently tart and herbal-spicy finish. nicely crafted wit with good use of barrel/bugs - respect JP et al.

Bottle 750ml.
Pours clear blond with medium white head. Minimal lacing. Aroma is of citrus, spices. Taste is of citrus, green apples, acid, spices. Palate: Light body. Medium carbonation. Overall: Refreshing. Nice citrus/spices. Well balanced. Nothing is too much.

Bottle (750 ml). Shared by czar, thanks! 

Appearance: Slightly hazy bright yellow/golden with medium to high white head and little lacing. 

Aroma: Some sulfur at first, but it dissipates quickly. Theres light spiciness (coriander), lemony notes, mild tartness (Jolly Pumpkin kind of tartness) and herbal presence. 

Taste: Moderate tartness with light spiciness (coriander), lemony notes, herbal presence and nice wheat presence.

Palate: Light body. Medium carbonation. Moderately dry. Lemony finish. 

Overall: Like the description is stating, its tart and refreshing. Definitely has the Jolly Pumpkin signature. Super drinkable and quenching. The tartness is very cohesive with the Wit features. Very good!

Pours a hazy yellow (or maybe light golden) with a medium white head that leaves really good lacing. Nose is of pils, herbs and spices. You can feel it is different from your usual wit. Taste is nicely tart and offers citrusy/lemon flavors along with spices and some light wheat notes in the background. Body is light and carbonation moderate, I think I could drink gallons of this. Overall a really nice and refreshing neo-wit.
Bottle - Funky brett, soured wheat and lemon. Cloudy light gold. Nice light tartness throughout, citrus and some light woody notes. Very nice and easy drinking, not sure it is worth the price though.

Bottle @ home, big thanks to Baron for sending! Initial pour is a clear golden appearance with an off white head. The aroma is fucking awesome. Twangy, tropical fruit Brett, some funk, pineapple, mango, and some bubblegum. Carbonation seems a bit dull but the flavor is otherwise nice. Lots of papaya, peach, pineapple, and passion fruit in the flavor. Light wood and brett. Super juicy and refreshing. Light acidity. Great fucking beer.

750ml bottle, from Dutchs. Shared with robotopera and co. Mostly clear golden yellow color. Mildly hazy. Thin ring of off-white head. Some dots of lace. Medium body. Smooth, crisp, lighter carbonation. Dry finish. Extremely refreshing and easy drinking. A little funk in the nose, some nice white-wine like oakiness. Awesome lemon citrus in the flavor and oak, light bit of spice (way less than your typical white ale, though). Moderate sour taste. Light sweet. Fantastic, refreshing bright lightly sour white ale. So refreshing and tasty, great to enjoy at the end of a humid 90F day.

Bottle @ Mikkellerbar, Viktoriagade. Pours unclear golden with a diminishing off-white frothy medium head. Aroma is lactic, apple, coriander, honey, orange, mild horseblanket, oak. Taste is moderate sweet, light bitter and mild tart with a fatty component. Body is light+, texture is thin, carbonation is moderate. Finishes sweet and mild lactic with apple.Great

Bottle at Mikkeller Bar, bottle date 2012-07-10. Crisp fruity, fruit stack, brett, orange zest, flowery, oak. Light body, oily texture and also light fat, medium/high carbonation. Light/medium sweet, no real bitterness, very light sour. Very refreshing and drinkable, tastes of more, more, more.
light sour aroma,pale, hazy, white foam, light sweetness, lightly sour, light body, oily feel, light dry finish do not like a witbier.
Orange coloured and hazy. Has a white head. Sweet aroma, light bread and some spice, fruity. Flavor starts sweet, a bit acid, tart too. Moderate bitter finish.
bottle. Golden with two finger head. Tart with plenty of Brett, though theres still plenty of room for the Belgian white spicing to show through. Really well done.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein trübes goldenes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch hefig, malzig, leichte Gewürze, fruchtig. Geschmack hefig, fruchtig, miniimal säuerlich, Citrus.
Smell of sour apple. Honey colour, white head. Aroma of apple, spices, cider. Sour. Very lively carbon.

Bottle shared with esp0r at BRU Pub, august 1st 2013. Hazy dark tint golden body, big white bubbly head.Funky aroma, wood, lemon and bread. Taste is yeasty, light sour hints, peach, some spices, Refreshing crisp tart aftertaste.

750 ml bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 7/10/2012. Pours moderately hazy golden straw color with a 2 finger fairly dense white head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Spotty foamy lacing clings on the glass, with some moderate streaming carbonation. Aromas of big tart apple, lemon, pear, clove, pepper, hay, grass, wheat, oak, vinegar, leather, funk, and yeast earthiness. Incredible aromas with awesome complexity and balance of yeast ester and oak notes; with great strength. Taste of tart apple, lemon, pear, pepper, clove, wheat, bread, hay, grass, oak, vinegar, leather, funk, and yeast earthiness. Fair amount of earthy tartness on the finish; with lingering notes of light fruits, pepper, clove, wheat, bread, hay, grass, oak, vinegar, leather, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a bit. Damn nice balance and complexity of yeast and oak notes; with a light malt balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium-high carbonation and light-medium bodied; with a very smooth, crisp, lightly prickly, and lightly acidic mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is a highly excellent wild witbier! All around great complexity and balance of oak and yeast ester flavors; and very smooth and crisp to drink. A very enjoyable offering.

Bomber at Top Hop with Stefan. Aroma is clean mild wheat with a tart note in the background. Taste is clean wit with mild tartness that balances very well. Finish is clean and quicker. Mouthfeel is very light and soft. Nice beer.

Bottle shared with daje & Carsten at Vulkan:BRU
Yellow hazy, white head. Smells of brett, malts, wheat, tart berries. Light sweet, fruity, some lemon and brett. Medium bitter finish. Interesting as always coming out of Jolly Pumkin
Drucken på flaska på Brekeriet bar i Djurslöv. Smak och doft av vete, citrus, jäst, nektarin, omogen persika. Lätt syrlig med god beska.
Drucken på flaska på Brekeriet bar i Djurslöv. En syrlig, frisk lätt amerikansk veteöl. Mycket citrus, nypon, omogen persika. Bra balans, fina smaker. Perfekt sommaröl. riktigt god.

Bottle at "Ölkalas hos Ekne". 

Hazy golden/yellow with a small white head. Aroma and taste of citrus, yeast, wheat and some malt. Also some light spices. Easy to drink with a tart finish.

Bottle at Monks. Mostly clear light amber pour. Soft lingering foamy white head. Strong carbonation. Medium-light body. Very smooth finish. Clementines. Bamboo. Lemon pips. Thyme. Buttered biscuits with marmalade. Bananas. Verbena. Despite its billing, reads only slightly tart and spicy. More a fuller, juicer, (and better) wheat beer.

Bottle thanks to Jay. Pours slightly cloudy gold with white head. Nose and taste of banana, lightly soured wheat malt, green apple, white wine, grape musk, wild yeast, peach, light coriander and lightly tart lemon. Body on the lighter side of medium.

750 ml bottle bought @ bierkompass.de. Pours hazy pale yellowish golden with a frothy white head that quickly dissipates while leaving a small trace on the glass. Smell is tart and fruity with crackers, apricots, mandarin oranges, white bread, lemon juice, sour milk, coriander, ginger, orange zest, lemon zest, hay, cloves, barnyard and hints of banana bread. Taste is tart and fruity with crackers, dried apricots, banana bread, hay, dry wood, white pepper corns, cloves, cilantro, thai basil, lemon zest, sour milk, lemon balm and barnyard. Mouthfeel is crisp, dry, tart and light bodied. Finish is tart and fruity with crackers, lemon juice, peaches, apricots, cloves, dry soil, dry wood and coriander. Great thirst-quencher!
A bit of coriander and orange. Lightly tart with a bit of wheat. Light and very easy drinking.  Pretty similar to Calabaza Blanca, but not quite as nice.

The beer is golden yellow with a small white head. The aroma brings citrus and pine hops. Light in body and sufficiently bitter. A bit watery and certainly refreshing. A nice brew to toss back on a hot day.
Bottle. Slightly hazy dark yellow with big white head. Aroma is malt, brett, yeast, wheat and a little wheat. Flavour is malt, brett, yeast, spices, wheat, little acid and a little oak.

a mild wild...pours cloudy yellow/white with a lot of citrus in the aroma and a little funk.  Big, full mouthfeel with orange, lemon, a little funk.  Highly carbonated, but appropriately for the style.  Finish is very dry.
Bottle. Pours a hazy pale yellow color with a white head. Has a fruity wheat malty spicy aroma. Fruity wheat malty slightly tart spicy flavor. has a wheat malty tart citrus finish.

750ml bottle. Hazy yellowish golden colour with huge, firm, frothy, long-lasting, moderately lacing, white head. Wheaty, yeasty and spicy aroma with notes of lemon, lemon zest, herbal overtones. Taste is minimally tart with a lemon note, an earthy herbal touch, a persistent bitter note.

from Erzbierschof - very slightly hazy pale golden beer with no head retention; strong aroma of curaçao with some coriander below; prefumy; pretty highly carbonated, some Jolly Pumpkin-like acidity, pretty dry with a long spicy finish with hints of vanilla and curaçao; fizzy and perfumy - charming

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2015 Referigerated 75 cl brown bottle through trade from FlandersNed.  Pours translucent golden small white head.  Descent lacing, medium body, low/medium carbonation, and tart aroma.  Taste is sour lemon.  Refreshing and very good.  Looses flavor after 16 months.

Poured from a 750 ml bottles. Pours a hazy, pale gold with a medium white head of foam. The aroma is pretty tart and lemony. Taste is pretty sour, especially for a wit. Not what I expected, but still pretty damn good.

August 8, 2012 - 750 bottle shared by blankboy with me, garthicus and biegaman.  ("Thank you!"  garthicus:"Is it his cock" / biegaman:"IS it his cock?" me:"yes, yes it is")  Hazy light yellow with a minimal fizzy white head.  Smells great - a real sweet/sour mix, lots of lemon, some wool, plus sweet lemon drops and dried wildflowers - (7+).  Taste follows, like a simple, sweeter/maltier lemony sour, not much alcohol, very easy to drink - light bitterness.  On the light side, mild carbonation, acidic, but not aggressively so, and it finishes quite quick - loved it.

My bottle [750ml] at Volo shared with HogTownHarry, garthicus & biegaman, August 8. Pours a hazy yellow with a spare diminishing creamy white head. Lovely sour aroma of citrus, more fruit, spice, yeast and herbs. Flavour is mouthpuckeringly tart, which I love, with lemon, herbs and a light sweetness. Average to medium bodied. Fantastic stuff!

With thanks to Blankboy for this treat for HogTownHarry a and my birthday. Appearance: hazy yellow, zero white head. Aroma: Sour, so sour, lemon, zesty, smells refreshing. Flavour: oh wow! Sour! Yay. Lots of lemon, makes my teeth fuzzy, I love it , yeast and just a wonderful oak, corriander  sour finish. Lovely.

Bottle-Purchased at Artale Wines in Rockford, IL June 2012-pours clear lite orange with a wispy white head that didnt last long.  somewhat fizzy appearance as well.  WOW, huge nose mostly lemon zest, sourness, lite spice and a bit of JP funk in there (Dexter yeast?).  Wow, this is not what you would expect for a Wit.  WOW, flavors are very sharp tart, sour, some lemons and some lite funk with a very long lemon zest finish.  seems more like a sour than a wit to me.  however, it is not a sour mash from what im told.  the wood from the oak shows up in the finish.  this beer is very solid and unique. Long tart and sour finish that lasts forever!   yet another winner from the guys at JP!

Fairly tart and funky aroma up front, some distinct coriander aroma, lemon, .... lively light lemon flavor, multi fruit, candylike fruitiness, finishes a little funky and tart, very very refreshing... super easy drinking... kinda geueze like... very nice... hazy golden with a small white head...

Clear, light gold, a very little bit of white head.
Scent is strong banana and coriander.
Taste is wheaty and tart, light fruit.
Very dry with a farmhouse funk finish.
Bottle.  Musty lemon, coriander, and wheat malt aroma.  Pale yellow color with small head.  Musty lemon and wheat malt flavor.  Dry finish.  Unmistakably a Jolly Pumpkin beer.
Bottle. Yeasty/musty wheat malt, white grape, coriander aroma,. Hazy yellow with a small white head. Musty, tart wheat malt, coriander flavor. Light body, dry finish,.
22nd July 2009Hazy pale gold beer. Light dry palate. Very slightly tart. Some orange citrus, light spice but it all gets way too dry - sucking every last drop of moisture out of your mouth!
A decent brett-infused witbier. It seemed to be quite the thirst quencher and fuller in flavor than most American or even Belgian witbiers.

[4289-20120209] Bottle. Light apple yeast aroma has light plank wood notes. Slightly hazy, light yellow orange body with no lasting head. Sour applesaucy yeast flavour has a great twang to it. Medium body. Good, would not have guessed it was a witbier. (7/3/7/3/13) 3.3
(@ Volo, Toronto, ON)

2012-02-09. hazy pastel yellow body, small-off white head. 3+ Pleasant aroma is modest, musty malt character, light funk, mild straw, grass and floral notes. Something I can not quite place is like a musty floral-honey melange but that is not quite it. 7+ Flavour is lightly refreshingly sour/acidic up front, with a wave of modest sourness across the tongue to your throat. Very light lactic quality to the sourness, especially in the finish. Undertones of lemon and grapefruit seed in the aftertaste. 7+ Smooth average to light body is softly carbonated. Nuanced and enjoyable, if drinking it on its own I would prefer a bit more oomph all around, but as it is it would be a nice companion to a meal. Enjoyable. Bottle at Volo, Toronto

Strong funky aroma, some liniment as well.  Attractive white body with generous big bubbled head.  Above average mouthfeel.  Tart not sour is the feature, with a witbier in the secondary.  Very drinkable.  Masterful.  But the aroma may scare off the timid.

Pours a rich hazy gold, darker than I would expect for a wit but beautiful nonetheless, big bubble head and moderate retention.  Aroma is fart-like yeast, some tartness from the wheat, brett funk, french oak, coriander, orange and lemon.  Taste is super tart lemon-lime-orange, grassy funk, peach and apricot emerge with time, pleasant buttery oak aftertaste.  Body is medium, velvety smooth, very low carbonation, tart/sour dry finish.  Overall, uncommonly low carbonation for the style but absolutely delicious.  Outstanding.

Sampled at an esbls tasting.  This pours hazy dingy golden and it has almost no head.  A sour fruity nose.  The flavor is quite smooth.  Vinegar is tasted but is not over powering.  Very drinkable for a non sour head likevmyself.

Jolly Pumpkins more pretentious younger brother.  This one was a bit one dimensional.  The base beer is kinda beat up a bit by the tartness.  A belgian wit really doesnt have the strength to hold up to the yeast elements that overwhelm the palate a bit.  Tasty and refreshing but nothing great for the huge price tag.
Smells like a jolly Pumpkin, tart lacto flavors. Sweetish some spice aromas. Creamy and tart but some smoofness to it. Very pleasant and refreshing

Bottle: &nbsp Orangish straw, very hazy, moderate to large sudsy white head, fairly nice lacing. &nbsp Funky 

nose, smells like a little Brett? &nbsp Otherwise some oak and subtle citrus spices. &nbsp Very tart up front, 

bordering on sour. &nbsp Starts out like a damn Sour Ale at first. &nbsp Spices show up towards the back, not too 

strong. &nbsp Seems more citrusy than anything else. &nbsp Also rather dry. &nbsp Interesting take on the witbier 

style, with its dryness and tartness up front. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate. &nbsp The finish isnt too spicy, 

well at least as spicy as I would have wanted it to. &nbsp Seems to have subtracted some spiciness in favor of the 

tartness and whatnot. &nbsp Interesting brew! &nbsp Thanks Kevin for the bottle!

Shenandoah Throwdown, 2011.  Very hazy pale yellow pour with a lot of carbonation.  Thin white head.  Bretty aroma.  Some dust, yeast and dankeness.  Dry, dusty flavor.  Tart with some doughiness.  Nice bitter finish with sour apple.  Easy drinking.

Brought a bottle to Shenandoah and we had this during the 2011 Shenandoah Throwdown.  Pours a lightly hazed gold with a medium sized white head.  Nice funk, wood, very light spice.  Sweet with a light amount of funk, toast and sweetness.  Soft and sweet, gentle funk and yeast, musk.

500mL at Shenandoah Throwdown. Pours a hazy near white color with a smaller, white head. Nose is salty opening up into some noticeable funk, sourdough, and lemon. Taste is chalky, sulphury, somewhat eggy. As it warms, it becomes very mild and lemony tart with a small doughy base. Extremely light and refreshing like lemon Gatorade. Tart, quenching palate. Pretty much a Calabaza Blanca clone with less noticeable funk in the nose.

Tasted on 7/19/11 from a 500mL bottle purchased at Binnys in Skokie.  Pours cloudy pale golden with a thick, pillowy white head that slowly recedes to spotty lace with a decent collar of lace.  The nose is very sour with lemon citrus, signature Jolly Pumpkin fruity funk, and a bit of pale malt as well.  The flavor is lighter in every aspect with the same lemon citrus sour and tart notes, pale malt, and fruity Jolly Pumpkin signature funk.  The body is light with very lively carbonation and a long fruity-funk and tart lemon finish.
Poured a hazy light yellow with a white head.  This is a really good refreshing beer.  Very well made.  More please.
Bottle dated 2/25/10 Clear pale golden yellow pour with no real head.  Citrus hops.  Crisp and very clean.  Very dry and champagne like. good stuff
Spicy, dry aroma, dried citrus peels.  Nice citric tartness.  Light yet rich mouthfeel.  Light farmhouse-style funkiness.  Lots of lemon.  Very nice.
Hazy yellow with a white head. Aroma is sweet, wheaty, yeasty, citrus and spicy - coriander. Flavor is medium sweet and light acidic. Bone dry finish. Reminds me of a saison. 030710

750 mL bottle from International Beverage in Grand Rapids, MI.  Pours pale yellow with a frothy white head.  Aroma of lemon zest and maybe a slight hint of coriander.  Wonderful lightly tart flavor yet the Belgian yeast adds to the body and helps balance this from being too tart.  This is every bit the equal of something like Jolly Pumpkin Calabaza Blanca more than your traditional Belgian Wit.  A great sour witbier.

Bottled. RBESG 2010. 
Hazy pale yellow colour with big white head. Aroma is fruity, bit lactic with a suggestion of coriander. Mouthfeel feels light, maybe due to the lactic sourness this beer suffered from, although its not clearly infected. The coriander is not very present in flavour.

750mL bottle.  Poured cloudy, pale golden with a short, tight white head.  The aroma picked up tart lemon and orange zest, cloves, and a touch of nutmeg.. peppery, very distinct yeast and some oak as well.. smelled like it was going to be refreshing.  The flavor opened with tart lemon zest and oak, followed closely by a spice wash (cloves, more citrus zest, and coriander).. the barrel carried it across the palate and the malts didnt play any more than a supporting role.. finished tart and refreshing with more zest and oak lingering.  Light-medium bodied and tart as mentioned on the palate.. really good stuff!

The aroma is a bit sweet with typical spicy notes of a white ale, but the aroma of refreshing tart comes and takes over. It pours a beautiful golden white color with a decent white head on top. The flavor of a white ale, a bit sweet and spicy, is then made even more delicious with that smooth tart flavor to round it off. It has flavor of granny smith apples.

Pale straw color, thin white head, moderate lacing.  Nose of light fruit, grapes, some tartness and sour mixed in.  Crisp, refreshing, really great balance of flavor elements, drinks more like a white wine than a beer but really delicious.

At YNWA, Kolding, DK.
Bottled, 030710.
Pale yellow with white head. Aroma of yeast and fruity esters. Flavor with wheat, spices and citrus. High carbonation - much like a Saisson

Pours a cloudy golden yellow that is slightly translucent with minimal white head.  Nose sour apple and butter.  It is immediately apparent that theres going to be a bit of twang in this wit.  And sure enough, there it is.  Sour green apple dominates, with a noticeable amount of orange.  The Jolly Pumpkin influence is really apparent here.  My only complaint is that the flavor is a bit thin, but thats probably more a product of the style than anything.  Nevertheless, an interesting take on the witbier that Id drink all the time in the summer if it was available in New England.
bottle at RBESG 2010 ... light fruit hop ... zezty fruit hop ...little sharp .. load of lemon
Bottle. Bit hazy yellow with a creamy big white head. The aroma is coriander, fresh fruit and light caramel. The flavour is light distinct sour, fresh fruity, light coriander and light citrus.

I had one of those "you know youre a beer geek when" moments when my heart nearly leapt from my chest when i found this gem on a store shelf in Chicago. Pours a nice golden color of course at the beginning of the bottle with perfect clarity, as the bottle drained of course it became hazier and hazier, but no less beautiful. The head is  medium white and leaves some lace. The aroma is very funky with some lemon rind and a slight alcohol character. There is some good barnyard aromas along with some citrus and new oak. The flavor follows perfectly dry with that essential lemon rind character. This beer is all kinds of tart with plenty of sourness however it has some great fruitiness and a mild malty and spicy character to it as well. Everything about this beer works in this sort of perfect unison. Of course you can tell that Jolly Pumpkin house character is in there, but I cant wait to see what these folks do at their own brewery, theyll be standing on the shoulders of a giant no doubt. 

 I wish I could drink this beer every single day, multiple times a day. The cost of something like this is of course is one of the biggest arguing points for working on your homebrewing chops.

Surprisingly funky. Ron Jeffries is all over this thing, which is obviously a good thing. Acidity comes through pretty strong in the aroma. Very refreshing. Nice lemon, orange, tangerine. Highly carbonated. Some plum in the back end.

Bottle shared by joshuahfl. Pours hazy ellow with a transient white head. Slightly fruit appleish aroma. Near medium body with spritely carbonation. Just a little bit funk. A little appleskin. Tart, but not strongly so. Shows JP influence. Quite nice. Definitely not a standard wit.

Bottled at Monks Café Wallingatan, Stockholm.  Hazy golden, faint head. Interesting aroma with brett and hay complimented by rosemary and vinegar. Dry and light bodied, slender and fresh. Notes of buckwheat, lemon and gass. Hugely drinkable, yet with remarkable complexity. My kind of beer!

Pretty good beer.  I didnt get much whale out of it,  not sure what was the point in aging this in a whale,  but whatever.  Gold pour with a snappy white head.  Lemon zest and funk around.  Flavor follows though,  some spice.  Lightly tart finish,  very refreshing.

750ml bottle, 2007 Vintage.  Pours a bright vibrant yellow body with a fizzy bright white head that had amazing retention and left tons of thick heavy lacing.  The nose is just awesome, bright and bretty with some floral and perfume qualities.  Theres tons of brett in here, yet it smells so clean and vibrant.  The flavor is as bretty as the nose indicated, this is as unlike any Wit as I have ever had.  Theres not over-spicing or any dumbing down going on here.  Its not quite as in your face as most Jolly Pumpkin beers are, but I really think its just delicious.  A little sweet, a touch sour, and so bright it just bursts on the tongue.  Lots of tropical fruits and just the lightest most subtle coriander and orange peel spicing.  Mouthfeel is light and airy with perfect fizzy lively carbonation.  Overall I liked this better than any White Ale than Ive ever had.  Delicious.

Bottle from Smiths.  Turbid golden yelow pour with 1-finger white head.  Nose is tart, limey, yeasty, with some hops and florals.  Tastes spicy, floral, with limey citrus, and legitimate hops.  Smooth on the tongue, and a bit like a slightly watered down gueuze with added sugar.

Bottle enjoyed at the NSSRQSOSLT, 1/10! No idea who brought this, but thanks! Pour was pale hazy hellow, nice head and lacing. The aroma was citrus, wheat, faint coriander. Flour was citrus (faint oranges, some tartness), wheat, lemons, faint yeast and a light sour finish. Mouthfeel is moderate for the style, a tad acidic. Decent but not great.

This poured a cloudy straw yellow color with a big fluffy white head. Aroma was tart, citrus and some spice. Flavor was a bit bland compared to aroma, fairly sour but not much other flavors. A bit one dimensional.

clear yellow, smooth lacing white head.
aroma is sour, white wine, yeast, wheat.
flavor is tart, sour, faint stable, quite refreshing.

At the RB Pgh gathering 12/09.  Thanks to Mr Chopin! Slight haze with a thin head. Clean fresh aroma. Some spice in the olfactory. Quite cutting on the carbonation and that is welcomed. Some fruit yet funky barnayard backgrounds lurkin in there. Some bitterness inthere but the fizziness is so attractive. Refreshing in its own sorttah way. Overall good tasting experience. Thanks Kev!
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle thanks to polomagnifico!Sharp blond with a foamy white head. Nose with impressive depth in pie crust, citrus, and an all-around barn note that reminds one this is brewed at JP. Flavor is less enticing with a more dominant citrus and wheat, some green fruit showing tartness. Thin but nicely carbonated. Quite a refreshing beer, though the funk was unexpected.

bottle, I have been looking forward to this one for awhile and finally got to try it, pulpy yellow pour with a funky lemon aroma, flavors of lemon grass, mint, some yeasty egg whites, nice sour finish
Bottle Pours out a cloudy gold topped with a white head. Aroma was light citrus and lemon zest a little funk. Taste was a lot like the aroma a little funk and tart. Thanks ditmier.
tall rocky head. aroma of lemon rind. hints of oak. so dry, so funky. this beer is one of the best ever made.

500mL bottle courtesy of xnoxhatex poured into a tulip.  My first beer from this brewery actually.

Pours a bright, hazy golden yellow with a big bubbly white head that is continually fed by a steady stream of bubbles from the bottom.  The lacing is very good and a rocky white cap stays on for the duration.

The aroma has tart lemons with a healthy dose of yeasty sourness and some barnyard funk creeping in.  There are plenty of spices, including clove, and bready malts in the background.

The taste is very tart up front, a combination of tart, sweet fruits and the Belgian yeast.  The bready malts form a backbone that gives way to a dry, yeasty finish with the funk lingering on the palate.

The mouthfeel is medium bodied and spritzy on the palate with lots of bubbly carbonation.  Its dry and much more tart than a typical Belgian wit, but its also extremely refreshing with the tartness really adding a complexity that I enjoyed.

Bottle. Aroma of brett, pineapple, lemon, grapes, wheat. Wheat comes out more in the flavor, which is also where the citrus and coriander notes can be perceived beneath the lightly tart funky component more prevalent in the nose. The combination of the base beer and the JP components work together nicely on this one to create a refreshing, dry, more-complex-than-just-pure-funky brew.

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy golden yellow with a thick white head.  Aroma of sour funk (barnyard), tart candies, lemon, bready malt, and light citrus.  Flavor is light and sour with bready malt in the background.  Overall, light crisp sourness with a touch of bitter hops.  Not really a witbier; this just tastes like the other Jolly Pumpkin sour ales or maybe a sour Belgian ale (pretty similar to Bam Biere).  Enjoyable.
7/4/8/4/15 [3.8/5]

This to me is a style that is less open to interpretation. Given that this poured with an excellent head with great retention and lace. Color is a straw/lemonade yellow. Aroma is fresh, tart, slightly malty and no spices despite label. Body was a tad thin but had good carbonation. Compared with the gold standard wits its ok; on its own a bit better. Finish is ok, short; nothing special. Session beer if youre into tart.

Another cool beer thanks to ditmier. Pours a clear yellow with a medium white foamy head. The aroma was almost like pine sol or a citrus cleaning solution- but in a good way! Sweet yeast and lemony flavors, pine, a sharp spicy mix and citrus bite. A very cool Witbier for sure. Dry and fluffy mouthfeel. A nice take on the style.

2009 Bottle - Thanks coyotehunter! - Pours a hazy dk yellow with a medium white head...aroma is similar to the other Leelanau bottles with a twist, funky still, with some citrus zest acnd pine that had to be pointed out, and a wit spice component, clove/coriander...flavour is fruity grain tempered with the barrel, again tart but not sour, spicy and fizzy...just a ridiculous take on a funky wit...

Slightly cloudy golden peach color with vibrant white head, and fluffy lacing.  Aggressive, balanced aroma with sour grapes and herbal/minty notes along with citrus.  Bubbly mouthfeel, like champagne with peach and apple puree.

Bottle. Poured a clear pale gold with a thick but light white head. Aroma is light and sweet, with grape and apple notes. Flavor starts with sweet fruit notes, but transitions to a surprisingly tart finish.

Quite enjoyable. Different than other wits. Nice citrus zest with a semi underlying tart quality. Some nice spice with a fairly rich body. A feel of some wood on the tongue and a hint of funk. Fairly complex and nice to drink.

Thanks a ton to the turd for sharing. Pours a cloudy pale yellow thanks to my agitation of the bottle. Head is two fingers thick sticky and offwhite. Aroma is very layered, peach skins start off, mildly tart and acidic, notes of oak, yeasty, fruity esters, mildly grassy. Flavor is nice and spicy, with a great level of acidity, yeasty and estery with a present oak/tannic character, citrus rind. Nice tart and dry palate. Fantastic.

Bottle from coyotehunter. Thanks!  Very nice wit, probably the best Ive had. Nice oak, lemon, citrus,spice, and lots of funk.  Great head and body.  Better than calabaza in my opinion.  Really enjoyed this one.

On tap at MBGSF09.  Poured a nice hazy golden color.  Great white head.  Light aroma, some soft wheat and lemon.  Taste was much the same, with hints of coriander and spice, and a touch of funk to round it out.  This was really refreshing, a great summer beer.  I would like to try this again.  A super solid offering for the style.

April(?) 2008:  Whaleback White has a hazy light golden appearance with a frothy white head.  It is dry with a very light spiciness, light bitterness and tartness, and some acidity.  Overall this is an interesting white but definitely takes a backseat to JP Calabaza Blanca...
750 mL bottle shared by Lance.  Thanks!  Rating #141 for this beer.

750 ml bottle not sure the vintage?  Classic Jolly Pumpkin aromas, tart, funky, oak, hints of vanilla, with a lemon zest citrus aroms.  Pours cloudy golden yellow with a solid white head.  Tart flavors, earthy, lemony, with some orange peel, hints of spices like corriander, very refreshing wit!!

Bottled (somewhere in Copenhagen pubbing). Hazy yellow colour with mediumsized creamy head. Aroma has lots of coriander, some wheat as well as some mild acidic notes. Flavour is wheat, a bit acidic notes, coriander as well as some fruity notes as well. Wellbrewed imitation of Wit.

Bottle. Poured a clear golden color with a thick white head. Very fizzy pour, but not a gusher. Good retention and lacing. Attractive aroma of coriander pale malt, and tart fruits (lemon, unripe apricot).  Light bodied and acidic on the tongue with plenty of effervescence. Lemon zest, coriander, white wine, and white grape flavors. Pretty good stuff.

Another winner from the folk at Jolly Pumpkin.  Pours clear yellow with a good sized white head.  The aroma has citric zest, spiciness, pepper, coriander, orange, lemon and crisp wheat.  Light crisp grainy body with lots of sharp carbonation with a large bubbly feel that really works for it.  The flavor starts out with lots of citric presence that leans more lemon that orange, the coriander jumps out and takes over.  The wheat taste is there, but stays in the background.  The finish is clear, spicy and has lots of citric acid.  The is very refreshing and wonderful.  Thank to Terminus for sharing this one.
Bottle. Hazy yellow with a small egg white head. Aromas of pepper, corinder, orange peel and lemons. Fresh and dry flavour with notes of citrus fruit and bitter citrus peel.

I had a long chat with the Brewer of this beer, his favorite part of this beer is the dry finish:
Bottle, Pours a hazy orange-yellow with a thin, foamy, white head that lingers. Aroma is sweet and sparkly, with a lot of yeast and fruit, Taste is fruity and clean, with a bit of sourness and yeast. Finishes a bit Dry with lingering sourness.

Been checking this one out for a while and decided to splurge Hazey yellowish pour with a frothy white head. Aroma of wheat, citrus, funk, some yeast and spice. Flavor is lightly tart and fruity, some vinnegar notes and typical JP funk, with tons of nice citrus, apricot, and spices. Lovely, bottle conditioned mouthfeel, medium mouthfeel, light oily mouthfeel, and soft carbonation. Dry, tart finish.  Fantastic wit.

Bottle 1pt. 0.9fl.oz. @ home.Unclear hazy medium yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is light moderate malty, wheat, citrus, orange peel, moderate yeasty, spicy, coriander, sweet vinegar - sweet lemon / citrus. Flavor is moderate to light light heavy sweet, light acidc, moderate to light light heavy bitter and sweet vinegar with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20090125]

Bottle from Beermerchant. Hazy pale golden with a big head. Sharp oakey and lemony aroma, somehow reminding me of a geuze. Tart, lemony flavours blending well with fat oakey vanilla. Some woody as well as acidic dryness. Quite full-bodied. A very complex wit that borders to a geuze. That combination does not fail to impress.

Bottled. A hazy golden beer with a thin off-white head. The aroma is sweet with notes of coriander and brettanomyces as well as light notes of citrus. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of orange peal and medium notes of malt, leading to a dry and tart finish. Thanks yespr for sharing.

Bottle.  Golden with an off-white head.  Aromas are yeast and strawberry with spices, citrus and melon.  Bitter lemon with floral notes.  Woody with ginger and traces of aftershave.  Flavours are citrus and melon with spices, cream and sweet wheat.  Yeasty with a dry finish.

Hazy golden with a small white head. Complex spicy aroma with grains of paradise, coriander and cilantro, with some earthy notes underneath. Tart and dry with spice and wheat malt flavour. Drying tannin in the finish.

50cl bottle. Pours a cloudy yellow with a solid creamy white foam. Nose is balanced - orange fruits, citrus, wheat, yeast & spices. Medium bodied. Taste has brett, barnyard, citrus and oak. Some sour & spicy notes. Very different from the regular Belgium Wit - complex, yet mild & refreshing. Ends dry. Good!
Bottle.  Golden beer with a strongish head.  The aroma is weakly citrus and spiced, and the flavour is sour and weakly spiced.  Overall a very average beer.
foggy straw pour with a small white head. taste is a little too tart for me, i like my white beer with a little more spice. this beer is worth trying!!
UPDATED: MAR 10, 2009 Light, refreshing, tart, some citrus. A light lactic acidity to the flavor. It is basically a JP brew.. probably Brett. Lemon, a little wheat. Very enjoyable.
clean nose light citrus flower and sour dough. light white lace on straw gold fog. smooth citrus flower and some ripe soft cheese funk on the back end.

Bottle. Pours murky orange with a foamy white head. Lots of carbonation. Aroma is of malt, wheat, oak, citrus, and tart fruit. Taste is of wheat, oak, malt, tart fruit, citrus, and sugar. The fruit is tart enough to be tasty, but doesnt overpower the other other flavors. Body is very light. Very acidic taste aided by the heavy carbonation. Not bad at all. Not worth $12, but not bad.

Bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of yespr. Pours a slightly hazy yellow with a dense, white and lacing head. Lightly tart Brett nose with a lactic touch. Light body with a heavy carbonation, a citrusy tartness and an oaky touch. Again a whiff of Brett. Dry and slightly astringent finish. Very refreshing. A unique idea to oak age a Belgian Wit, but quite surprisingly it works! 010209
Pours a hazy dull yellow color with a big creamy white head. Nose is lemon, lactose, and vinegar. Taste is the same with a meaty wood component. Tangy. Not bad.

Bottle, bought @ Ølbutikken, Cph.
Pours hazy golden with a medium, frothy, slightly off-white head. Aroma is tart, lots of brett, some oak, lemons and wheat. Highish carbonation, a little thin mouthfeel. Flavour is nice, quite balanced, but there is not much of it. Dry, lemony, apples and wheat. Quite drinkable, but it is quite mild.

Clear gold with light, bubbly white head / Nose of tart orchard fruit, wood, and brett / LIght body, moderately tart, with good balance and finish / Flavors of lemon, apple, oak, and funky brett / The weakest effort by Jolly Pumpkin, although the obviously not of their design.

Bottle thanks to ilovedarkbeer. Pours with a foamy, white head over a hazy yellow body. Aroma of funky Jolly Pumpkin yeast, honey, coriander, pepper and orange. Taste is slightly sour with oak, coriander, citrus, clove honey and orange. Fizzy and dry mouthfeel.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2009 Big thanks to ogglethorp.  Aroma is pleasantly yeasty, has earthy spices, but also has a sour funk that kind of overpowers lightness of the other smells.  Pours a hazy pale straw gold with a huge open white head, beautifully effervescent.  Flavors are a delicious fruit basket complemented by a dry tartness.  Pear is the dominant fruit, pineapple and general tropical tart sweetness round out the profile.  Flavor ends in the creamy funkiness that was kind of off in the aroma, but nicely complements the flavor.  Long lasting tart afterglow.  Palate is perfectly effervescent, and yet somehow smooth.  Awesome beer.

50 cL bottle. Pours hazy yellow with a small white head. Dry brett wooden aroma with a mild fruity note. Refreshing citric fruity flavoured with a nice fruity to floral flavour. Mild tartness into a refreshing finish. vague wooden note. Nice one. A bit too thin body.

bottle 50 cl. large fizzy white head that mostly diminish. Cloudy straw yellow color. Spare lacework. Wheat, citrus, fruit, sour notes. Medium bodied with an average carbonation, dry texture. Light to moderate sour and sweet flavor. Dry fruity sour finish.

Clear pale yellow pour with a big, rocky, white head and a constant stream of bubbles from the bottom of the tulip glass.  Looks very much like champagne with a Belgian head.  Lots of sour, bretty aroma with some notes of coriander, lemon zest, yeast and bread dough.  Very sour and acidic flavor with some straw background and notes of coriander, yeast and lemon.  Very dry, medium-light body with loads of carbonation.
Bottle at home - New Years Tasting. Clear yellow - White head. Horsey, acid, brett, wheaty, spicy, citric, barnyard, artificial, rubber, yeasty, soapy.

50 ml Bottle with The Club. Pours a pale hazy yellow with a white head. Smells sour and of yeast. Light sour with a low sweetness. Citric aromas of yeast.  High carbonation. Medium to light bodied. Dry finish.

Bottle.
Cloudy yellow coloured with a medium sized white ehad.
Fruity aroma of spices, brett and citrus.
Light acidic flavour of citrus and brett with notes oof overruped fruits.
Tart finish of citrus and hops.

Lys klar gul med et lille hvidt skum.Dufter af citrus,er syrlig, rengøringsmiddel og gær. Smager af gummi, eddike, sæbe, marcipan. Er i det hele taget en meget væmmelig og syrlig oplevelse. Er den mon fra Samsø?

750 ml bottle.  Light pour with decent white head.  Aromas were citrus and fruit.  Flavors were similar with hints of spice and a slight wheat twang on the finish.  Pretty decent tartness in the aftertaste.  Pretty good.

Bottle courtesy of Styles shared with Turbo during his feedom holiday.Aroma of dry grains and coriander. Gold body with white head. Grains again in the flavor along with a sweet sourness. Dry on the palate. Thanks Chris

Bottle. High white creamy and lasting head. Slightly hazy light yellow body. Sweet nutty fruity aroma with citrus overtones. Lemon prevails in the flavor. Long lasting aftertaste and a low carbonation.

Bouteille de 750 ml partagée lors dune dégustation Ratebeer Montréal chez MartinT. Arôme: Odeur dananas avec une pointe citronnée. Apparence: La couleur est blonde blanchâtre. Présence dun moyen col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de zeste de citron avec une pointe de coriandre et dorange. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement minérale. Forte effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de coriandre en arrière goût. (Rating #2050)

750ml Bottle:  Lightly tart aroma of yeast, apples, tart fruit, and slight spices.  Poured yellow/pale gold in color with a large, foamy, white head that lasted throughout.  Hazy.  Sparkling.  Many medium-sized particles.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor is lightly sweet and light to medium tart.  Tastes of wheat, tart fruit, light spices, yeast, and lemon.  Light to medium body.  Tingly, effervescent texture.  Lively carbonation.  Slightly tart, lemon and spice finish is dry.

Lightly hazed straw color with a tall bubbly white head. Lightly tart wheat aromas. Fairly simple, yet appropriate with some lemon peel and a hint of cardamom. Lightly tart from the start as well. Nearly sharp and biting in feel. Some hints of wheat and some more lemon zest. Not much spice presence a bit of mace in the finish. Dryer finish with some more acidity coming in. A tart wit. Would be good for a summer day, a loaf of bread and some cheese and grape.
Golden-hazy with a medium white head.  Aroma is quite citrusy with a classic wit aroma and some spice.  Flavor has some nice citrus astringency with some gentle wheat and mild yeast.  Good wit.

My Bottom Line
A most seductive perfume of pineapples, lemon zest, pears and frolicking funk is daubed onto soft wheat, coriander and spicy bitterness for yet another tantalizing Wild Witbier creation from Jolly Pumpkin.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A sheet of foam covers the cloudy blond.
-The chosen oak barrels are just perfect for this beer.
-Carbonation is frothy and beautifully enlightens the mouthfeel and ebullient flavor profile.
-The tropical fruitiness is eloquent and so pleasurable.
-Brettanomyces and lactobacillus seem to be enjoying each other quite a bit.

Bottle.

Bottle.   Pours hazy straw color with a dense white head almost like egg whites whipped to stiff peaks.   Aroma is orange zest, yeast, light funk, grains.   Flavor is lemon zest, orange, coriander, pale malts, yeast.   Palate is light bodied, high carbonation, finished lightly tart and refreshing.   Excellent.

Bottle. Pours a hazy orange-yellow with a thin, foamy, white head that lingers and a lot of floating residue. Aroma is sweet and sparkly, with a lot of yeast and fruit, reminiscent of champagne.  Taste is fruity and clean, with a bit of sourness and yeast. Finishes a bit watery. Lingering sourness. Kind of strange but it works.

Pours a light and hazy, pale straw color.  A fizzy, snow-white head settles to a small but well retained layer.  Spotty lace marks the glass.  As expected, the nose is very much like a Jolly Pumpkin brew.  Tart lemon and orange rind add a distinctly citric acidity, why a dry, pale wheat background is spiced with light coriander and perfumy, floral hops.  Dry, funky oak notes finish off the nose.  Flavors are dry, citric, and refreshing.  Lemon stands out as the dominant fruit component, but lightly sweet orange is present as well.  The coriander is subtle, which is a good thing, and the signature JP oaken yeast funk permeates everything.  Light to medium bodied, well carbonated, and dry, the palate lends a refreshing drinkability.  Better than Calabaza Blanca, this is Ron Jeffries’ greatest witbier effort to date.

Crisp hazy golden coloured body with a white head and nice bubbles rising from the bottom and sides. Aroma of curacao, coriander seed, lemons and a ton of wheat and malt - nice! Medium-bodied; Strong assertive wheatiness with yeast and coriander seed most prevalent. Aftertaste has some sweetness and the lemons/curacao also come out. Overall, a very nice wit - damn good for the style! I sampled this 750 mL bottle (looks more like the old Stoudt’s bottles - at 765 mL) purchased from Merchant’s in Dearborn, Michigan on 03-August-2008, sampled on 13-September-2008 on the Eastern Shore of Virginia.

First Beer since Burning Man, damn I needed this.  750ml, from Dalekliz, thanks.  Very nice champagne like quality to the initial pour.  Pours yellowy orange with a tan head.  Nose is very champagny, slightly tart and fruity.  Taste is fruity, light and quite refreshing wtih a lot of carbonation.  Pretty good.

750 ml bottle generously shared by theisti. Pours a bright golden yellow with a thin white head and patchy lacing. The nose is of a nice, sour citrus, Belgian yeast, a light woodiness and a faint spiciness. Light to medium-bodied, it is slick yet dry with a mildly tart/sour finish. Bright tart/sour citrus fronts a subtle, woody, Belgian funk. This is a very nice beer. I’m not sure that it tastes much like a traditional wit, but it is very good. Thanks for sharing this one with me, Tim!

750 ml bottle courtesy of Thaichile. Pour is clouded golden yellow with a snow white 2 inch head. Nice streaked lacing. Aroma of tart, citric earthy yeastiness. Some wheatiness under that. Taste of tart, slightly sour wheatiness, some bright lemon peel citrus.  The bitterness really brightens up the finish.  Some grassy hay yeast elements in the finish as well.  Palate is thin to medium, a little slick making it very drinkable. Thanks for sending this one my way Mark!

Pour is effervescent looking lightly hazed golden with a nice tight bubbled white head...bubbles constantly float up the outside of the glass....beautiful...smell is woody funky with cheese rind and it just reeks of brett...some pepper and coriander too...taste is bright and tart at first with a nice bright citric quality revealing some of the spices...some clove, coriander, white pepper...then citric tartness...wow...

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2008 In short: A smooth extra-bretty slightly spicy and very funky beer.  A great Bam Biere alternative
How: Bottle 750ml, consumed 2 months after purchase
The look: Cloudy yellow body topped by a large white head
In long: Nose has typical Jolly Pumpkin funky barrel signature.  Extremely bretty, lively carbonation, somewhat lemony, medium acidity, high tartness level, some orange and lemon peels, some coriander, dry sandy finish.  This is a Bam Bier but a little less bretty and some added coriander and dry orange skins.  A fantastic beer.  Im starting to believe that its not the Jolly Pumpkin brewer that is the key, its all about the barrels.  To me it seems that anything you put in those barrels comes out amazingly pleasurable.  How big are these barrels? Cause you see Ive got this girlfriend

cloudy pale gold with a long lasting egg shell white head. The aroma is strong with the lemons and a fresh floral character, like dandelions. Bright and clear, this is like smelling a lemonade while having flowers bloom on your porch. The taste is lightly tart with some dry hay notes in the finish. There is also some oaken woodiness. The really high carbonation is sharp and nearly bites the tongue. This has a lot more character than most wits, not for the timid.

750ml bottle.  Aroma:  Very funky and sour lemon, light pepper and coriander, oak.  The funky lemon is really upfront and smells great.  Appearance:  Light golden in color and hazy.  Bright white head was full and foamy with great retention.  Great lacing.  Flavor:  Lemon and light funkiness, oak and coriander.  Some very light tropical fruit notes into the finish.  Nice tartness throughout.  Medium dry finish.  Palate:  Medium-light bodied.  Medium high carbonation.  Overall:  A very different take on the Wit.  I enjoyed it a lot, but mostly for the sour and funkiness.

750mL Bottle. Pours a fluffy deep cloud, slightly clouded, with a tall rocky white head. Aroma is fragrant and smooth in passionfruit and palm sugar. Delicate and breezy. Flavor moves similar, adding pineapple, certain Brett and citrus to the wind. Very refreshing. The palate is very moving, but doesnt let flavor linger long. Explosive and evaporative. Fluffy. A great bright fresh dry and slightly sour tropical flavor pairs beautifully with the heat and sunshine. Nice.

A nice, but a little sweet witbier. Aroma of coriander, orange and soda. Pour was a light gold with a nice 2 finger white head. Taste was a little sweet. Sugar, coriander and spices with nice carbonation and a sweet wet aftertaste. Almost tasted and looked like ginger ale.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle that holds a hazy, pale yellow liquid that supports a massive, fluffy, white head with sour aromas hitting my nose before Im even done pouring.  Closer inspection confirms the lemony aromas and some sidenotes of lemon and grass.  Flavor is wonderfully tart... lemon peel and spice, but comes off as very refreshing and crisp. At first I thought it seemed pretty thin and unidimensional, but I really like how it all hangs together and consider these "flaws" to be strengths after further consideration.  Wish I had bought a couple more bottles since I dont know when Ill see this again.

text: Pours a nice cloudy yellow, with some pretty, visible carbonation. Wow, what a head...I poured the beer two minutes ago and the head is still growing in the glass. The aroma is quite tart - definitely reminds a bit of a sour. Lemon, spice, a little bit of wheaty funk. The flavor is good, but a little bit on the mild side. A bit sour, tart, lemony, spicy, but these characteristics are all pretty watered down. Decent mouthfeel, pretty lively carbonation, very light, which is about right for the style I would say. Solid, easy drinking beer, but not the best Wit out there.
Bottle: One of the better witbier that I have had.  Aroma and flavor of coriander and spices.  Very good.

Pours cloudy yellow golden with a great medium creamy white froth on top (that head is spectacular).   Huge wild yeast, oak, sour, funky lemon aroma.  Not many traces of a Belgian White here.... pretty far gone into the sour ale segment.  Very sour tart lemon flavor with lesser oak notes.  Easy drinking.  Extremely light and airy, unexpectedly large carbonation, and watery finish.  The label is a sticker... good for putting on xnoxhatexs back when hes not looking... so I guess thats a plus
Pale yellow and clear hue with a white frothy head.  Sour yeast and fruit flavors.  An ok brew but too sour and yeasty.  Below average.

Nice pale yellow pour with good white head. Nose is very funky, barnyard stink, mild lemony fruit and a good touch of grassiness. Big pleasantly tart onset, some citrus fruit, more barnyard funk. Rolls towards some peppery spiy notes with a touch of clove. Ends pretty clean. Body is juicy with some playful carbonation. Woody notes become more evident on the finish as it warms. Getting some apricot and peach as well now and a hint of bandaid on the nose.

Long history with this beer. Got this while ago in a trade from MI2CA, Ted always hooks it up. However, I did not enjoy the bottle, did not even rate the beer.  But recently tried it again @ Bar Great Harry in Brooklyn.  This time it was a very different and much more interesting experience.  Pours a very extraordinary pale color, yet you cannot see through it.  Has a small head to go with that. Its a very lemon-y and tart brew with touches of acidity (not much).  But the I loved the drink-ability of it.  It was almost like an Uber Berliner Weisse.

text: Pours a cloudy yellow with effernescent head that fades fast to a whitel lacing.  It looks very refreshing.  The taste is a bit too sour for me to be very refreshing.  I thought that it was alright but in general it was a letdown.  I do like the champagne feel (very dry too) but the sourness is too much.

pours a cloudy yellow with a fluffy white head.  the aroma is sour, with some graininess.  the flavor is also sour (a bit more than just tart).  over all, the sourness and a certain flowery sweetness is the dominate trait.  the found the palate to be s little bubbly.   didnt find this one to be very refreshing.

750 ml bottle
I found this at Bella Vino a few months ago.  It was time to crack it open since this is not exactly a beer that struck me as a good candidate for any more aging.  Its probably the least interesting in the Jolly Pumpkin lineup to date.  However I think that has more to do with the style than anything else.  Its hard to get excited about a light sessionable witbier when you know what else is available.  I still recommend giving it a shot if you can find a fresh bottle.
Aroma / Appearance - A fast growing head took over most of the glass.  It took quite a while to settle down to something reasonable.  When it did I admired the carbonated transparent golden body underneath.  This had all the hallmarks of a light sessionable starter.  The nose was pretty clean - white pepper, lightly aged oak and honeycomb.  A florally playfulness kept it all together.  It was somewhat like fresh hot popcorn without that cheap movie butter.
Flavor / Palate - The mouthfeel was spicy and carbonated.  Honeydew melons blended with lemon zest and apple cores made the otherwise simple experience worthwhile.  This was perhaps a bit more like an apple cider than a beer.  On the other hand it is very sessionable and did not take long to finish off.  Try it before you crack open that three year old bottle of Expedition Stout or Dark Lord.
750ml. A kick ass witbier! very spicey and some tart. Some coriander, orange and citrus. Very nice and refreshing!  Could easily down a lot of these

750ml bottle and a thanks to holdenn for sharing. ive wanted to try these JP contract brews for quite some time. this is very ala Jolly Pumpkin with their house funk nose and flavor. the coriander, orange peel, and wheat were pretty under played as the dry funkiness took over. which is a plus for me as im not a big fan of this style when its at its most straight forward or typical. reminded me a lot of JP calabaza blanca and also really under-rated.

Classically married coriander, spice, and citrus zest aromas with a palate full of fresh bursting tangerine and brushy notes though till the finish. Its a frothy and cloudy beer with a light fresh apple-juice-like color.

Let me make this clear - Im not going to rate this as a Witbier. This is a funky saison. Basically Bam Biere, which is not a bad thing. Pours an absolutely beautiful, almost clear gold with fast moving beads of carbonation. Thick bone white head leaves lacing forever. The smell is chock full of brett and oak. Super funky, with farmhouse, stinky cheese, apples, ginger, pepper, some anise, and tons more. Beautifully complex aroma. Taste funky as all hell! Sour acidic flavors burst forth with apple, pepper, spicy and citrus notes following. Finishes super dry, with long lingering brett acidity, slight hop bitterness and a pleasant nutty flavor. What a beast of a beer! The mouthfeel is a bit over carbonated in my opinion, but overall this is fantastical. I look forward to seeing what the future has in store for Leelanau. Im thoroughly, thoroughly impressed. Its great to see these wonderful Belgian traditions being reborn in the states. Beers like this make me hope that hoppy was just a fad, and wild beers are here to stay. Im keeping my fingers crossed..

Very golden almost yellow body with a beautiful white head leaving laces; Beautiful elevated well developed well composed citrus fruity fresh nose, very very good; Super well made body, complex, balanced and very pleasant, slightly sour super interesting body; It finishes super balanced evolving perfectly, great length, fades perfectly with a late pleasant fresh sour bite and lots of balanced aromas. My favorite white, YES SIR!!!

25.4 oz bottle.  Clear straw yellow with a light white head.  Mild funky lemon reveals some honey.  Crisp and bubbly with very subdued sour lemon and just a hint of wheat.  Coriander and oak emerge with drying.  Pouring in the sediment softens the citrus and carb leaving traces of paste.  Quite nice with enough of the JP touch to keep it interesting.

Poured a hazy light yellow color with a small white head.  The aroma is tart and yeasty with a little funk.  Light spice and leathery notes.  The flavor was tart to start with some leather and lemon acidity.  Hint of spice.  Very mouth watering.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2008 2/23/08  750 ml bottle thanks to tytoanderso.  Pours a hazy orange yellow with a tall white head.   Nose is reminiscent of Jolly Pumpkin.  Citrus, orange peel, wheat, the slightest sour and funk notes.  Similar flavors that are dry, tart, and slightly funked.  Id really like to see more of the tart and funk come out of this.  Last time I had it, it seemed infected in a bad way (tomatoes?) but this time Id like to see more of the funk in the way of barnyard that is present with most JPs.

Sampled at RAYBOY01s Cajun Fais-Do-Do.  thanks to el_boracho.  Pours yeah like that picture.  Cloudy white/yellow with a white head.  Aroma is strange lots of orange, lemon citrus, and acidic vegetable/tomato.  Like cheap tomato sauce.  ok.... I tasted that acidic tomato only one other time, with a Jolly Pumpkin Grand Reserve Firefly, maybe im more attuned to that note, but Im not enjoying it.  Alright Im finished.  6/3/4/3/10

Cloudy Yellow Color with White Ring. Lightly Spiced with Alot of Lemon Zest on the Nose.  Thin Bodied..Nice Hazed Flavor Mix of Citrus, Dry Spice and Yeast..with Subtle Sweet Malts....and a Drying Citrusy Aftertaste.  Tried on 2 Separate Occassions and Both Instances Were Different...One Being Fairly Zesty and the Other Quite Flat on Lemon Sparks, but Still Nice and Even Keeled.

Bottle courtesy of El_Borracho. Consumed at Rayboy01s Cajun Fais Do Do. Fruity, Belgian aroma; fresh. Nice! Cloudy gold body with excellent white lace. Served too warm. Sour but not overly so. Actually not bad.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2007 Part of the many beers tried at RAYBOY01s Cajun Fais-Do-Do, thanks el_borracho.  Cloudy yellow with nice white head.  Spicy, sweet malt aroma. Orange, spic, sweet.  Thin, well carbonated.  Pretty tasty.   7/3/7/3/15----Tasted again on 12/20/07---- 750 from sicilianos in grand rapids, MI.  Tasted alongside bam biere and bam noire.   Clear straw color with medium to large white head. Draft sample at MBGF07. Pours hazy yellow color with an average ceamy white head that was mostly lasting with fair lacing. Moderate sour citrus spicy and woody aroma. Light to medium body. Medium sweet & sour flavor with a medium sour citrus finish of an average duration. My expectations where met.

Pours with a fully hazy, yet bright yellow-straw colored bee.  It is topped by a pillowy, frothy, pale, off-white colored head that starts out a full four fingers in thickness; the head dissipates at a medium pace, but always keeps the beer fully crowned by at least a thin layer of froth.  The aroma is a mix of damp spices; sort of a mix of a damp, freshly rained upon earthiness, some definite orange zest, a smooth lemon-like & cleanly earthy coriander note as well as a mix of ginger, white pepper, something floral (like mix of honeysuckle & orange blossom).  This has a fantastic nose to it; quite vibrant & actually quite spice dominated, yet the spices are so well integrated that they are not too much.  There are some hints of funkiness here, but for now they are really quite soft.

Quite dry and it is well carbonated as the beer froths up as it hits my tongue for the first time.  The bone dry character of this beer accentuates a nice, almost biting, tartness that, with the orange zest notes, makes this beer taste lemon like.  Despite coming from the Jolly Pumpkin brewery, this is actually quite clean tasting; I wouldnt guess there were any wild bugs here.  There is a soft oak character to this beer though; it is barely perceptible at first, but contributes a oak-like spiciness as well as a touch of tannic backbone.  Both of these wood-derived notes are noticeable in the finish.  The wood is actually at just about a perfect level of flavor integration; it is subtle enough that it is almost not noticeable, yet it does contribute to the character of this brew, even if it is just a supporting role.  Soft, zesty notes of coriander sort of blend with the spicy oak notes.  The beer is not nearly as spicy in the flavor as it was in the nose; ultimately I think this is a good thing as it allows hints of barrel notes as well as a soft wheat character to come through in the flavor.  Flavor notes of orange blossom honey, subtle-yet-sharp lavender, white pepper and young ginger are all noticeable in the taste.

This is a very nice example of a Wit beer.  Despite the fact that I was hoping for some wild funkiness (which is certainly not here), I am really enjoying this beer.  I really like the mix of spice notes, grain character and the fact that this is bone dry and so light and drinkable; truely a perfect warm weather drinker.  I am a sucker for Wit beers and this one really hits the style & more importantly it hits the spot that satisfies my craving for tasty Wit beers.  This is possibly one of the best, non-funky Wits out there.

750mL bottle, no date.  Pours a slightly hazy straw with a 2 1/2 finger bone white head with lots of lively bubbles in the body.  Great retention.  I was told this was oak aged and contract brewed by Jolly Pumpkin.  I can smell them both here.  Aroma of lemons, acidic sour funk, dry wood, and light spice.  Flavor is much the same with an added earthy bitterness and stale hops somewhere.  Just after the swallow some lightly sweet malts come in to knock out any lingering bitterness.  Very refreshing.  Lots of carbonation with a light to medium body.  A most excellent witbier.

RBSG 2007.  Yellow color with a thin head.  Aroma of coriander, orange and wheat.  Lots of wheat in the flavor with a bit of lemon.  Nice to have some lemon in a wheat without having it come from a slice.

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2011 Bottle. Sample from the Minnesota distributor.  Pours hazy yellow with a thin bright white head. Bottle from Beastiefan2k at Spuytin Duyvil. All anyone wanted to do was make fun of this beer, but I thought it was quite decent. Very nice, super pale pour with a good white cap. 750ml bottle, little cloudy gold with dense white bubbles, light spices and floral fragrances, faint sweet and pilsner malt with a citrus sour, pilsner, grapefruit juice tartness and spice taste, dry on the palate, lots of carbonation, light on the tongue.

Sweet, light floral funk aroma, some spice, some pepper, a lot of lemon.  Light, airy palate.  Sharp tart start moves to mildly sweet, dry citric finish.  Light, sour, and dry.

Bottle shared at the Columbus Tasting V: Pale yellow pour with a white head. Aroma of lemon zest, funk, bret, sour and yeast. The flavor was composed of some funk, sour notes, lemon/lemon zest and a some yeast. Light mouthfeel, lively carbonation with a dry/sour finish. Pretty damn nice.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2007 Bottle courtesy of northerntimber.  Pours a beautiful cloudy amber/yellow with a well maintained fluffy white head. UPDATED: DEC 22, 2006 2006 bottle (750mL) enjoyed at Slows BBQ on 11/5/06Magnificent amounts of creamy white head are slow to recede.  The body has a typical haziness of other JP beers, though still demonstrates a fair enough clarity.  Appropriate white-gold and lemon colored Belgian wit color.  Sheets of lace cover the glass.  Excellent appearance as usual from JP.Tart, even a touch sourish nose is full of vanilla wafers, gobs of honey and bitter lemons.  The esters immediately go to work on the malt, bringing it down to nearly nothing and providing an excellent crispness.  Spicing is moderately done, contributing a dry, leafy coriander note, with airy white pepper and juicy lemon sugar cookies (from a mix of the citrus zest and pils malt).  Some lactic notes are evident on the finish, giving it a bit of a hard edge, which somewhat detracts from this more playful of styles.  Strength of aroma is high, with no alcohol or flaws.  Barrel character contributes some tannins, giving a slightly sharp note as well.Fluffy, pastry dough crust is injected with more vanilla wafers and then drizzled with lemon icing.  Suddenly someone spills a few drops of 3F lambic in the pie.  Light sourness takes hold, followed by a very crisp finish filled with perfumey esters, dry fruit skins and fresh, chewy coriander.  Some nutty wood notes help control the sourness somewhat, and light oak oiliness adds a strange twist on the belgian wit bier style.  Tight, engaging carbonation greatly helps out where it can, and a not (yet?) too underattenuated body throws enough sweet, honeyish malt in to the equation.  Dont get much wheat flavor/aroma, though it no doubt contributes to the head retention and texture.Still, if youre going in to this expecting hoegaarden (which you shouldnt be), youre not going to be a happy camper.  Youve definitely got to enjoy what Ron is doing to get in to this one.

750ml - Yeasty aroma with a lemon-orange zing, green apples, coriander and other zesty spices.  Pours transparent yellow with a huge fluffy head and great lacing.  Flavor is very citrusy and spicy.  Pear and other light fruit with a big yeasty finish.  Palate is crisp and tart.  A funky and very tasty treat.

Very refined -- almost like a combination between a white and champagne.  Light grain and spice flavor behind a wonderfully pungent combination of sourness and dryness.  Very unique.  Best consumed after substantial aging.  Refreshing in an unusual way.  This would go well with sushi.

Bottle from trade with Jim (walleye).  Thanks!  Smell is full of lemons, apples, spices, and other fruity flavors.  Taste is very similar, with an almost sour apple kick to it. Certainly not what i was expecting at all, but I must say that if I could buy this every day I would drink it about that often, especially in the hot months.  Brewed by Jolly Pumpkin?  Interesting.  Very nice beer, extremely underrated.

hopdog opened up a Calabaza Blanca side by side b/c I was suspicious about this being the same brew. The Calabaza Blanca is more sugary, with pronounced orange(while this was lemony), and less tart than this.

Poured a hazy golden color with a small, white head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of sweat, citrus fruits, pedio, leather, citrus, spices, and some brett as well.  Taste of citrus fruits, grape skins, tart green apples, and a sour finish.

from the bottle. poured a lemonade with a big bubbly white head, that left some  lacing. aoma big yeast lemony, sourness, coriander, and some other spices that I could not figure out what they were do to the sourness masking them. flavor big hit of lemon and surpisingly got some nice sweetness, than the yeast. I would of like this yeasterday after I got done mowing the lawn very refreshing and easy drinking. but just wondering since this was brewed by Jolly Pumpkin which of thier bers is this close to? I do not recall any of thier beers tasting like this.
Pours cloudy gold color.aromas of citrus with flavors to match.Also had some sourness.The sourness also ended this brew
750 ml bottle. Cloudy yellow in color with a nice lacing. Peppery and lemony aroma. Lemony flavor. Finish is sour. Ok beer.
750 ml bottle. Small head and beer as light as the picture. Aroma is peppery and reminds me of Oro de Calabaza. Taste is too many lemons and limes though, way too sour like limeade.

(750 ml bottle: Obtained in trade with Pailhead, thanks Kevin!) Im opening this beer with the intention of getting in a quick rating right before going to work, and then bringing the rest of the bottle for my co-workers.  But only if the beer is good, so well see.  First impression: this is perhaps the most sour witbier Ive ever had!  Its very lemony, tart and acidic.  Honestly, this is pushing toward lambic-like sourness, though the lemony sourness does fade off the palate fairly quickly.  Lots of funk right from the start, but especially in the finish.  Lightly bitter orange peel is definitely there, most noticeably in the finish, but the coriander is barely recognizable behind the sourness.  Aromas of funk, sour lemon, and a moderate mustiness take me back to those thoughts of lambics again.  Light bodied, but very clean and crisp, nicely carbonated, and very refreshing.  Man, I could drink this all day (foreshadowing intended).  Very bright, radiant pale yellow in color and fairly cloudy, the beer has a thin, snow white cap.  Large patches of lace remain on the glass for quite some time.  Once past the initial shock of, "Hey, this isnt a witbier!", I think this beer is great.  Crisp, sour, funky, refreshing.  Ive enjoyed this beer so much, Ill definitely brought the second half of the bottle to work with me.So I brought the beer to work (a liquor store) and let my co-workers sample a few ounces.  Everyone really liked it.  I kept sneaking into the break room to sip on this beer for nearly two hours, and the beer only got better as it warmed up.  The lemony sourness subsided somewhat, and the coriander picked up, so the beer evolves wonderfully, becoming more balanced and more closely resembling the witbier I was expecting.  And the head maintained that cap for the duration.  Just an outstanding beer that I think should be well-chilled before serving, but give the beer plenty of time to warm up and evolve.  A wonderful first start for Leelanau Brewing, and now I really cant wait for their next masterpiece thats due out in March, 2006.
I love this beer!  perfect color for a white.  Heavy on the citrus, no need to add a lemon wedge.  It is good to go.  Very refreshing for a summer drink
